Posts.Content: May 8, 2011 05:14PM Nopey wrote: Thanks for responding, Faith.  Yes, my initial dx was stage IV IBC. Only treatment offered was to go on femera - no surgery, no radiation no chemo. At that time, I had a faint red line (it did disappear over a month or so) in area that is now fully  inflamed . This inflammation is new. Hard not to get concerned and think that this means disease progression. I do see my gyny doc tomorrow for my annual exam and will absolutely have her take a look at it.  Just thought someone might have had experience with this and ... you know... tell me that it is a benign inconvenience.

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2010 02:18AM Nopey wrote: Dear Bo I embrace you and hear your angst. It is tough enough to deal with this when one has confidence in care providers but majorly anxiety-provoking when one cannot trust them.  You have a host of knowledgeable survivors here offering good advice.  Hope you can find a good advocate as 'Bernicky' suggested to ease some of the concerns. Eight months ago when I got this DX, fearing I was going to die in a number of weeks was very real for me. Today, I plan to live long and die of something else.  Best of luck for next week.
